vs 𓎟 All Allah Ali


This artefact from the Danube Boian culture 4300–3500 BC might seem boring to the modern eye. But such a geometric symbolic object was a novelty appearing in a world which was still dominated by hunter gatherers and neolithic farmers. The 𓊹 symbol on it could easily be rejected as coincidence if it wasn't for the trace of the unbeloved swastika symbol, which also spread from the Danube to Sumer, Indus and beyond.

Although Egypt is renowned to be polytheistic, we often find text which just reference "the God". Other times we find collections of praises such as 𓎟𓂋𓐍𓏜 “All Wissender”, “All Rechter”, “All Reckoner”, “All Xander”...

Archandrupolis hinter Naukratis

𒀭 D'INgir ⇔ Dinger Dingis Deins Theis Theus Zeus Deus … Angel?

𓊹 > P
𓊹 paglus flag falk 𓅆
𓊹 •Panter پرچم parčam bayraq ⇔ *pleh₂- flat, broad, plain
𓊹 pono (post) pole < paglus pózna poznō Pfosten post perche pertica
𓊹 पताका patākā brattagh (flag, banner) ⇔ Bretter? branch? parch?
𓊹 •Panter ⇔ pointer?

From Proto-Italic *perth, *pertikā, see also Oscan 𐌐𐌄𐌓𐌄𐌊 (perek, “pole”, Umbrian 𐌐𐌄𐌓𐌊𐌀𐌅 (perkav, “rod”. Possibly from Proto-Indo-European *pertʰ- “pole, sprout” (Ancient Greek πτόρθος (ptórthos, “sprout”

Los Todos: Add Edda אתא (ʾāṯāh, “sign” and Arabic آية (ʾāya, “sign

𓊹 hagia / monk@monastry 𓐛𓉐𓏤𓊖 𓍏𓇯𓉐
